awd_titl_txt: Spatially-resolved infrared absorption spectroscopy of individual semiconductor nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Masaru Kuno of the University of Notre Dame is developing an instrument and related techniques to conduct chemically-specific single particle infrared absorption measurements.  The development of a single particle mid-infrared absorption microscope advances the ultrasensitive quantitative identification of samples.  Potential uses include the detection of single virus particles, which is an important research topic given its close connection to human health and homeland security.  An outreach program developed by Professor Masaru Kuno for area middle schools allows students and teachers to explore infrared imaging using low cost heat imagers now available for smartphones.  This smartphone application enables the students to explore and see the practical uses of blackbody radiation (light that is emitted depending on a body's temperature).

Basic science problems to be addressed by Professor Kuno include investigating the intraband and intersubband transitions of individual semiconductor nanostructures.  This research focuses on the use of Single-particle infrared absorption measurements.  Such meansurements are distinguished from existing single particle microscopies in that they operate in the mid-infrared fingerprint region and exceed the optical diffraction limit.  The infrared technique is multimodal and enables both visible and infrared single particle absorption measurements.  The technique is inherently fast and can rapidly acquire large area infrared images (centimeters) as well as spectra.  The infrared absorption measurements can ultimately be applied to specimens under native conditions without the need for additional sample enrichment or purification.  This research is an important  given the potential applications of the materials in infrared photodection. por.por_cntn:
Spatially-resolved infrared absorption spectroscopy of individual semiconductor nanostructures (CHE1563528)

Masaru Kuno

University of Notre Dame

Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry 

 

Summary of project outcomes:  

     Measurements of single particle infrared spectroscopic absorption on systems ranging from individual particulates to quantum dots represent the next frontier in understanding the chemical, optical, and electrical properties of matter. The goal of this and other like efforts is to unmask the ?individuality? of molecules and semiconductor nanostructures in a manner akin to surveying individuals as to their personal preferences in ice cream flavors and/or college football teams. Only in this way can we transcend existing knowledge limitations regarding how matter behaves and interacts with light. This is especially important since over 200 years of work now exists on observing and understanding the average behavior of matter. One can liken this limitation to only knowing that the most popular ice cream flavor in existence is, on average, vanilla.

     Unfortunately, few ways exist for conducting single particle/single molecule optical measurements. The majority entail looking at the emission from surveyed specimens. However, not all things emit light or emit efficiently. Consequently, objects that are non-emissive or which have low emission efficiencies are effectively invisible to existing spectroscopic techniques. We cannot study them. A strong desire thus exists in the scientific community to overcome this limitation so that we can more generally study the optical response of matter.

     Through NSF funding, we have recently developed an approach to conduct single particle infrared absorption measurements. This development is notable for two reasons. The first is that we focus on absorption which is a universal property of matter. All matter absorbs light and hence the developed technique is general. Second, measurements are done in the mid-infrared part of the optical spectrum. This is of note because there exist chemically-specific absorption transitions for molecules and other chemical species in this region. This is why it is often referred to as the ?fingerprint? part of the electromagnetic spectrum. In fact, traditional infrared spectroscopy, which surveys averages, is the basis for how many chemical unknowns are identified.

     We have demonstrated the superior sensitivity of our technique along with its ability to measure the response of individual particles in very close proximity. Think of this as being able to zoom down from outer space onto two individual standing less than 6 feet apart and asking them what ice cream flavors (or college football teams) they like best. We have also demonstrated that our technique can be used to characterize relevant, real world, materials used in next generation solar cells. We have even applied our technique to studying micro- and nano-plastics now found (at least by all media accounts) to be ubiquitous in the environment. In effect, we have shown that we have a versatile approach for conducting highly sensitive, single particle studies with real world relevance. One can envision such technology being eventually used in a myriad of applications, including those linked to homeland security.

     Beyond this, our NSF funded study has aided the training of graduate students in cutting edge science and technology. Students who have graduated have gone on to secure employment in the private, technology sector. At least one now works for a defense contractor.
